items.author: Richard Schickel
items.content: A war film that, entirely aware of its genre's conventions, transcends them as it transcends the simplistic moralities that inform its predecessors, to take the high, morally haunting ground.
Spectacular, wrenching masterpiece that unflinchingly documents the random horror, the grisly spectacle and the ugliness of war.

items.author: G. Allen Johnson
items.content: The effect is riveting and frightening. You feel you are under siege with the combatants.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: A bitter, bloody masterpiece with adrenalized emotions and hyper-realized images, this is perhaps as close to battle as any sane human being should ever hope to tread.

items.author: Maitland McDonagh
items.content: The movie's greatest strength lies in phenomenal performances that reach from the leads right down to the smallest supporting roles.

items.author: Ella Taylor
items.content: If Steven Spielberg's emotional intelligence matched his visual genius, his honorably flawed new film might qualify for one of the greatest-ever American WWII movies.

items.author: Stanley Kauffmann
items.content: Steven Spielberg's new film begins as a monumental epic; then it diminishes; and, by its finish, is baffling. [August 24, 1998]

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: Nothing that suggests an independent vision, unless you count seeing more limbs blown off than usual.
